awd_titl_txt: Conference: Geometric representation theory and moduli spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in a three-day workshop on recent advances in geometric representation theory and moduli spaces to be held October 20-22, 2023 at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. The workshop will focus on recent advances in geometric representation theory (the theory of symmetries) and moduli spaces in algebraic geometry (the study of zeroes of polynomial equations). The workshop will consist of ten to twelve talks spread over three days, allowing plenty of time for additional discussions. Participation of graduate students and postdocs will be encouraged. 
 
Spaces that parameterize geometric objects are known as moduli spaces, and are central to the study of algebraic geometry and representation theory. There have been many recent developments on moduli space theory, perhaps the most significant is the emphasis of general stack theoretic results over traditional Geometric Invariant Theory based approaches to moduli space theory. Moduli stacks of bundles over curves are closely related to the theory of conformal blocks and the geometric Langlands program. A recent development has been a twisted theory of conformal blocks. There have been a series on recent developments in the geometric Langlands program, and connections with arithmetic are getting more apparent. Affine flag varieties (including affine Grassmannians and semi-infinite flag manifolds) are known to be related to representation theory of affine Lie algebras, quantum groups, and algebraic groups. The workshop will focus on these topics, and bring together experts in these areas, with an emphasis on the work of younger mathematicians. The workshop website is https://tarheels.live/grtm/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the support of this award, Prakash Belkale and Jiuzu Hong organized the workshop on Geometric Representation Theory and Moduli spaces at UNC Chapel Hill, from Nov 17-19, 2023.  This workshop focused on geometric representation theory and moduli spaces, including progress on geometric Langlands program, conformal blocks, and representation theory related to the geometry of affine flag varieties and Grassmannian.

There were 11 talks at the workshop: two on Friday, 6 on Saturday and 3 on Sunday. These talks were each an hour long. The details are in the conference website: https://tarheels.live/grtm

The workshop emphasized the work of younger mathematicians, to advance their professional development, and to facilitate interaction and promote collaboration with more senior researchers.  In this workshop, 3 of 11 speakers were postdocs, 5 were assistant professors, and another 3 were more senior. 

This workshop was an important training opportunity: about 45 attended the lectures. Travel support from the grant was given to  9 graduate students and 5 postdocs. There were many fruitful interactions among participants which were reported to us,

Expense report: 

  1. Hotel for speakers:  $5898 (Hampton inn at Carrboro). 
  2. Other expenses of speakers (travel+ per diem): $9651
  3.  Other participant expenses:  $8974
  4.   Coffee/Catering:  $1223 

Total expenses:  $ 25746

During the conference several mathematical connections between the participants were formed. For example, Richard Rimanyi (UNC) and Yixuan Li (Berkeley) started mathematical discussions, that resulted in Yixuan Li giving an informal seminar lecture to two UNC faculty members (R.R and Lev Rozansky) and their four PhD students on the day after the conference. The topic of this promising starting interaction is the super- algebra version of geometrizing quantum group actions in the style of Okounkov and his co-authors, as well as its motivations from superstring theory.

We conducted an anonymous survey among participants. Here are some of their responses: 

“Great workshop! ”

“Talk schedule was kind of strange, it would have been better to have more talks Friday or Sunday and fewer on Saturday. 

“Due to the Thanksgiving Holiday, hotels are REALLY expensive during this time, but UNC conference housing is cheap and available, it would have been nice if this option was mentioned in advance in the conference announcement. ”

“Very nice conference. “

“Interesting topic and discussions ”

“A lot - I learned new insights from hearing others' work; I got useful feedback after sharing my work to participants senior to me and/or from different interests. ”

“I got to reconnect with some people I would not otherwise see, and get a sense of how my field interacts with representation theory. ”

“The talks gave a great window into what other researchers are currently working on, and I feel that I learned a few new things. I also had the chance to discuss with many people in between talks, including collaborators, other researchers, and also junior people such as postdocs. There is no substitute for having these discussions in person, in my opinion, and again I feel that I learned a lot from these discussions! ”
